DOC.HD: Nothing Beats It for Making a Real Splash
DOC.AU: Diane Pucin; Mike DiGiovanna; Bill Plaschke
DOC.LD: McCovey Cove is more than just a place for kayakers to dive for home run balls. It is a good place for TV cameras to turn if a Giant game gets boring.
At least that's what Giant President Peter Magowan said.

"Sometimes when you have a blowout or a game where people's attention wanders, you can show the Cove," he said. "I remember one game, where things were a little out of hand and somebody in the Cove hooked a halibut. It was a great shot."
DOC.TE: Instead of the rally monkey, maybe Giant fans can get behind the hooked halibut.

Magowan also continued his crusade for quicker games. His rant focused on the fact that, as he said, "What do you tell a father who takes his son to the baseball game and after two and a half hours, only four innings have been played?"

After singling out Angel pitchers Ramon Ortiz and Kevin Appier as slow workers who dallied too long between pitchers, Magowan admitted that "our guy last night" also was culpable. Livan Hernandez was taking upward of 60 seconds between pitches.
"I believe the commissioner is taking this very seriously," Magowan said. "Something needs to be done."
--Diane Pucin

MY TWO SONS: Shortly after the Angels lost to the Boston Red Sox in the 1986 American League championship series, which they were one strike away from winning until Dave Henderson's devastating Game 5 homer off Donnie Moore, Angel owner Gene Autry took general manager Mike Port and manager Gene Mauch out to dinner.
The conversation that night, as Port, the current interim Red Sox GM, told Boston Globe baseball writer Gordon Edes this week, went like this:
Autry: "You know how important it is that we're a family, that we have camaraderie, and I love you two guys like my sons. Next year, I want you to do everything you can to win it all."

Mauch: "Well, Mr. Autry, that's great, and I appreciate that, but a lot of things can happen over the course of a season -- you can have injuries, slumps, some guys might not perform as well as you expect. What happens if we don't win it all? Will you still love us like sons?"
Autry: "Yes ... but I'll miss you."
--Mike DiGiovanna
NOT-SO-FOND MEMORIES: It may be the Giants against the Angels, but ultimately, the older, deeper, far more bitter Giant-Dodger rivalry always seems to surface, even in the midst of the World Series.

When Kirk Gibson's pinch-hit home run in Game 1 of the 1988 Series was voted baseball's ninth-most memorable moment in a credit-card promotion, the fans booed loud and long while chanting the familiar, "Beat L.A.! Beat L.A.!"
IT'S A CELEBRATION: Odd enough that the Angels' John Lackey was the starting pitcher Wednesday on his birthday.
Odder still, he is the second pitcher from a Southern California major league team to start a World Series Game 4 on his birthday.
In 1988, Dodger Tim Belcher beat the Oakland Athletics in Game 4 on his birthday.

ANOTHER FIRST: Renal Brooks-Moon of the Giants, only female African American public address announcer in the major leagues, became the first woman to serve as a public-address announcer in the World Series.
--Bill Plaschke

DOC.HD: Dressing up your Halloween pumpkins at the Arboretum
DOC.LD: Halloween, our famous night of fright, is just around the corner. Most likely you are thinking about Halloween costumes, trick-or-treating and carving pumpkins. Pumpkins are a big part of Halloween. Although most famous as happy or scary jack-o'-lanterns, they are also an important food that is good for you.

Pumpkins are members of the squash family and grow on vines. The pulp inside pumpkins is used to make pumpkin pies, bread or even ice cream, while the seeds can be roasted and eaten as a nourishing snack.
Pumpkins come in all sizes, so picking one that's just right to decorate is always fun. Some of the largest pumpkins in the world weigh more than 1,000 pounds.
DOC.TE: Imagine how long it would take to carve and decorate a pumpkin that large!

There are many creative ways to decorate pumpkins without carving them. One fun and interesting way is to make faces using natural plant material that you find on the ground. Use berries, acorns, pine cones, seedpods, sticks, bark, feathers, leaves, fallen flower petals, moss or other plant matter that you find to create "spooktacular" eyes, noses, mouths, ears, eyebrows, eyelashes and hair. Glue and stickpins will help hold everything in place.

On Saturday, from 10 to 11:30 a.m., children 3 to 8 can learn to decorate pumpkins naturally at a pumpkin decorating event at the Arboretum of Los Angeles County in Arcadia. Reservations are necessary; please call (626) 821-4624. And be sure to wear your Halloween costume for the Peacock Parade! For more information on children's programs at the arboretum, visit www.arboretum.org.
This learning link was provided by the Arboretum of Los Angeles County, 301 N. Baldwin Ave., Arcadia.

DOC.HD: 'One Plus One Equals Two'
DOC.DH: The story so far: Sabina's volunteer project has begun.
DOC.LD: "They're cool!" Sabina exclaimed when the two art students brought in 10 identical posters. She held one up so everyone could see. "You're real artists!"
In bright red letters the top of each poster read "1 + 1 = 2." Under that was a short statement telling what those numbers meant, and in the center was a picture of a small child reading a book.
"Ms. Fishgold helped us," the boy said. "It was fun."
DOC.TE: "Paul and I thought we should tack them up right near the school entrance and in front of every water fountain," Matt said. "What do you think?"
"Sounds great." Sabina smiled. "And we'll need boxes or barrels or something to hold the books."
"We can ask at the supermarkets for boxes," Rachel suggested.
"I'll go with you," one of the committee members offered.
"And maybe the custodian has some extra barrels."
"As leader of this drive," Paul said, "I think you should announce the start of the book drive on the school intercom tomorrow, Sabina. How about it?"
Sabina felt her face heat up and looked away.
"Aw, she's blushing." Paul tossed a wad of paper at her.

That night Sabina went through her own old picture books. Some, like "Stellaluna," she loved a lot. Her father used to read it to her when she was younger, just before bedtime. It would be hard to give that book away. Or what about the wonderfully scary "The Ghost of Nicholas Greebe"? She loved books. They gave her so much to think about. Still, she selected five books she had read again and again, books she hoped some other child would love as she did. Tomorrow she would bring them to school.
Tomorrow: Will other children do the same?
